query: {"prompt": "What do I do if my account was locked during sign-up?"}
expected_response: If your account is locked during sign-up, [contact DigitalOcean support](https://cloudsupport.digitalocean.com) so we can authorize your access to your account.

query: {"prompt": "Why do I have to keep entering a verification code when I log in?"}
expected_response:
DigitalOcean accounts with email and password sign-ins and no 2FA are protected with device verification by default. Each time you sign in from a new location using a new device or a different web browser, we email an authorization code to the email address you use to sign in or send an SMS to the phone number you provided.
You may be asked to verify your browser from a trusted location and device if you have deleted cookies for digitalocean.com or you have disabled cookies entirely. To allow your browser to be recognized, you can allowlist the verification domain, `siftscience.com`. or pause ad blocking on `*.digitalocean.com`.

query: {"prompt": "I lost access to the GitHub account I use to sign into DigitalOcean"}
expected_response:
If you have lost access to your GitHub account, first try to restore access by following GitHub's account recovery process or 2FA credential recovery process:
* https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/github/authenticating-to-github/updating-your-github-access-credentials * https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/github/authenticating-to-github/recovering-your-account-if-you-lose-your-2fa-credentials
If you can't regain access to your GitHub account, [open a support ticket](https://www.digitalocean.com/company/contact/support) using the email associated with your DigitalOcean account and let us know you need to reset your authentication method. We need additional information to verify that you are the account owner, so be prepared with a photo of your government-issued ID (for example, a passport, driver's license, or military ID). The name on ID in the photo must match the name for the account information that we have on file.

query: {"prompt": "How do I log in if I lose my two-factor authentication device?"}
expected_response:
If you've successfully entered your username and password but don't have access to your 2FA device, you can log in using the backup method you chose when you set up 2FA, which is either backup codes or SMS.
# Recommendation * **Backup codes**: Locate the backup recovery codes text file, which by default is called `digitalocean_backupcodes.txt`. Use one of the codes by logging in to the [control panel](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/login) and clicking **Enter a recovery code** at the bottom of the **Two-factor authentication** screen. When you use the code, you cannot use it again, so you may want to mark it as used or delete it from the file.
* **SMS** Log in to the [control panel](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/login) and enter your account credentials. Click **Send an SMS instead** at the bottom of the **Two-factor authentication** screen. This sends an SMS with a verification code to the phone number you entered when you configured SMS as your backup method. Enter the verification code at the prompt, then click **Verify Code**.
After you log in, update your 2FA device or [disable 2FA](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/accounts/security/2fa/#disabling-two-factor-authentication).
If you can't use your backup method to access your account, [open a support ticket](https://www.digitalocean.com/company/contact/support) using the email associated with your DigitalOcean account and explain that you need to reset your backup method. In this case, we require additional information to verify that you are the account owner, so be prepared with a photo of your government-issued ID (for example, a passport, driver's license, or military ID). The name on the ID in the photo must match the name for the account information that we have on file.

query: {"prompt": "How do I open a support ticket when I can't log in?"}
expected_response: If you can't sign in to open a ticket, send a support request through the ["Can't sign in?" form](https://www.digitalocean.com/company/contact/support).

query: {"prompt": "Do paid DigitalOcean support plans support multiple teams?"}
expected_response: Our support plans do not currently cover support for multiple teams. Each team must have their own support plan.

query: {"prompt": "Can I move Droplets to another team?"}
expected_response:
It is currently not possible to transfer Droplets to another team.
# Recommendation DigitalOcean does support transfering a snapshot of a Droplet to another user on a different team that can then recreate the Droplet from the snapshot.
To transfer a Droplet using snapshots:
1. [Take a snapshot of the Droplet](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/images/snapshots/quickstart) 2. Once complete, [transfer the snapshot](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/images/snapshots/how-to/change-owners/) to a new owner. The new owner must [accept the transfer](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/images/snapshots/how-to/change-owners/#receiving-a-snapshot)
3. The new owner can then [recreate the Droplet from the snapshot](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/images/snapshots/how-to/create-and-restore-droplets/).

query: {"prompt": "What is secure sign-in for teams and how do I enable it?"}
expected_response:
Secure sign-in is a team setting that requires each team member to sign in to their DigitalOcean account using either 2FA, Google SSO, or GitHub SSO. This adds an additional layer of security for all team members.
To enable secure sign-in, navigate to your [team settings](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/account/team) in the control panel. This setting ensures that all team members use secure authentication methods when accessing your team's resources.

query: {"prompt": "What are the predefined roles available in DigitalOcean teams?"}
expected_response:
DigitalOcean teams come with six predefined roles: **Owner**, **Biller**, **Billing Viewer**, **Member**, **Modifier**, and **Resource Viewer**.
Each role has different levels of access: - **Owner**: Full access to shared resources, billing information, and team settings - **Biller**: Full access to billing information only, no access to shared resources or team settings - **Billing Viewer**: Limited read-only access to billing information, no access to shared resources or team settings - **Member**: Full access to shared resources, read-only access to team settings, no access to billing - **Modifier**: Full access to shared resources except delete operations, read-only access to team settings, no access to billing - **Resource Viewer**: Read-only access to shared resources and team settings, no access to billing
For more details, see the [predefined roles documentation](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/roles/predefined/).

query: {"prompt": "Can I create custom roles for my DigitalOcean team?"}
expected_response:
Yes, you can create custom roles for your DigitalOcean team. Custom roles allow you to create roles with only the specific permissions you choose, providing more granular control than the six predefined roles.
# Key Features - Custom roles are available at no cost - No limit to the number of custom roles you can create - You can modify permissions after creating a custom role - Team members can be assigned custom roles the same way as predefined roles
# Important Considerations - Custom roles can only be created in the control panel (not via API or doctl) - New product permissions are not automatically added to custom roles - You cannot delete a custom role if team members are currently assigned to it - Custom roles cannot be copied between teams
For step-by-step instructions, see [How to Use Custom Roles](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/use-custom-roles/).

query: {"prompt": "How do I create a custom role for my team?"}
expected_response:
To create a custom role for your team:
1. **Switch to your team** in the control panel by clicking the team icon and selecting "Switch Teams" 2. **Navigate to Settings** → **Role Access** tab 3. **Click "Create Custom Role"** to start the three-step process:
**Step 1: Create New Role** - Enter a name and description for the role - Select the permissions you want to include - Required permissions are automatically added (e.g., read permissions for resources you can modify)
**Step 2: Related Permissions** (optional) - Review and optionally add suggested related permissions - These are not required but may be useful
**Step 3: Assign Role** (optional) - Select existing team members to assign to this new role - You can skip this and assign members later
After creation, you can edit the role's permissions or delete it from the Role Access tab using the "..." menu.
# Note You cannot delete a custom role if team members are currently assigned to it.
For step-by-step instructions, see [How to Use Custom Roles](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/use-custom-roles/).

query: {"prompt": "What's the difference between a Member and Modifier role?"}
expected_response:
The key difference between Member and Modifier roles is their access to delete operations:
**Member Role:** - Full access to shared resources (including delete operations) - Read-only access to team settings - No access to billing information
**Modifier Role:** - Full access to shared resources **except delete operations** - Read-only access to team settings - No access to billing information
Both roles have identical access to team settings and billing (read-only and no access respectively). The Modifier role is designed for team members who need to create and modify resources but should not be able to delete them, providing an additional safety layer.
For more information, see the [predefined roles documentation](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/roles/predefined/).

query: {"prompt": "Can a Billing Viewer see all billing information?"}
expected_response:
No, a Billing Viewer has limited read-only access to billing information. They can view most billing information on the Billing page tabs, such as payment methods and promos.
However, **Billing Viewers cannot view billing settings** on the Settings tab of the Billing page.
For full access to all billing information including billing settings, a team member needs the Biller or Owner role.
For more information, see the [predefined roles documentation](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/roles/predefined/).

query: {"prompt": "What happens to API token permissions based on team roles?"}
expected_response:
Personal access tokens for the DigitalOcean API inherit their permissions from your team role. When Read Only and Full Access tokens scopes are selected, the permissions of your team role control the scopes available to your API tokens.
# Key Points - Personal access tokens are unique to the person who generated them - Your team role determines what API scopes your tokens can access - If your team role changes, it affects what your existing API tokens can do
# Example If you have a Resource Viewer role (read-only access), your API tokens will only have read-only scopes available. If you're promoted to a Member role (full access), your API tokens will then have access to create, update, and delete scopes. If Custom Scopes were selected when generating the token, the token will maintain the selected scopes even if your team role changes.
For more information about API tokens and scopes, see the [API documentation](https://docs.digitalocean.com/reference/api/create-personal-access-token/).

query: {"prompt": "How do I create a new team on DigitalOcean?"}
expected_response:
To create a new team, click the profile icon in the top right of the DigitalOcean Control Panel to open the drop-down menu, then click **Create a Team**.
The creation process has three steps: 1. **Team Info**: Enter the team name and contact email 2. **Add Payment Method**: Enter payment information (skipped if you already have a payment method) 3. **Invite Team Members**: Optionally invite people via email or skip to remain on a team of one
You must have a payment method associated with your default team before you can create additional teams.
For more information, see [How to Create New Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/create/)

query: {"prompt": "What happens when I sign up for DigitalOcean regarding teams?"}
expected_response:
When you sign up for DigitalOcean, you are automatically the only member of your default team. You can work by yourself on this team of one, or you can collaborate with others by inviting them to teams you own.
Teams are available at no cost and you can create multiple teams with any number of team members. Each team is billed separately and has its own payment information.
For more information, see [How to Create New Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/create/)

query: {"prompt": "Can I remove someone from my team, and what happens to their access?"}
expected_response:
Yes, team owners can remove members from a team. In the Team Settings page, find the member in the Team Members section and click the **...** menu next to their name, then select **Remove member**.
When you remove someone from the team, it removes their control panel and API access to that team's resources immediately. For more information, see [Manage Memberships](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/manage-membership/).

query: {"prompt": "What can I do if someone hasn't accepted their team invitation yet?"}
expected_response:
For pending team members (those who haven't accepted their invitation), you have two options in the **...** menu:
- **Resend email**: Sends the invitation to join the team again - **Cancel invite**: Revokes the invitation to join the team
The Status column will show "pending" until they accept the invitation, at which point it changes to "joined".
For more information, see [Manage Memberships](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/manage-membership/).

query: {"prompt": "How do I switch between different teams I'm a member of?"}
expected_response:
To switch between teams, click the profile icon in the top right of the DigitalOcean Control Panel to open the drop-down menu. Click **Switch Teams**, then click the team you want to use.
Once you switch teams, you'll be working within that team's context and can access that team's resources, billing information, and settings based on your role permissions.

query: {"prompt": "What's the difference between teams and organizations on DigitalOcean?"}
expected_response:
Teams are how you manage your infrastructure and billing on DigitalOcean. Each team is billed separately and has its own payment information. You can group related teams into organizations for consolidated billing, payment, and invoicing.
# Recommendation Use teams to organize resources and collaborate with others, and use [organizations](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/organizations/) when you need consolidated billing across multiple teams.

query: {"prompt": "What happens when I change someone's role to owner on my team?"}
expected_response:
When an owner changes someone else's role to owner, a special confirmation process occurs:
1. The original owner receives an email with a link to confirm the change 2. Once they confirm the change, the invited owner receives an email invitation to accept the new role 3. The role change only takes effect after both confirmations are completed
This two-step process ensures that ownership changes are intentional and verified by both parties.

query: {"prompt": "What is Single Sign-On (SSO) and what protocols does DigitalOcean support?"}
expected_response:
Single sign-on (SSO) is authentication mechanism that lets users access multiple applications by signing in once with a single set of credentials. An identity provider (IdP) is an authentication service that manages user identities for applications.
SSO on DigitalOcean supports OIDC-compatible IdPs, like Okta. When a logged-out user tries to access an SSO-enabled app, the app redirects the user to the IdP to authenticate using secure protocols like SAML or OpenID Connect (OIDC).
For more information, visit [Single Sign-On for DigitalOcean Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/settings/single-sign-on/).

query: {"prompt": "How do I enable SSO on my DigitalOcean team?"}
expected_response:
To enable SSO on your DigitalOcean team, first configure your IdP, then configure SSO on DigitalOcean.
Switch to your team in the control panel, click the profile icon → **Switch Teams** → select your team. From the team settings page, in the **Single sign-on (OIDC)** section, click **Enable**.
You'll need to provide three pieces of information: - The **OpenID provider URL** - The **OpenID client ID** - The **OpenID client secret**
After entering these values, click **Test SSO config to continue** to verify your provider URL is valid before proceeding to the next configuration page.
For detailed setup instructions, see [How to Configure Single Sign-On for Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/configure-sso/).

query: {"prompt": "Can I enforce SSO as the only sign-in method for my team, and what are the risks?"}
expected_response:
Yes, you can enforce sign-in via SSO only, which prevents team members from signing in to DigitalOcean with other login methods like email and password.
During SSO setup, use the **Enable sign-in via SSO only** checkbox to make your selection. If you don't enforce SSO during initial setup, you can enable it later on your team settings page.
# Recommendation Test your SSO login before enforcing sign-in via SSO. If SSO is misconfigured and enforced as the only sign-in method, you cannot log into your team and will need to contact support.
For setup guidance, see [How to Configure Single Sign-On for Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/configure-sso/).

query: {"prompt": "How do I configure role mapping between Okta groups and DigitalOcean team roles?"}
expected_response:
To configure role mapping, create a group in Okta for each role (predefined or custom) that you use on your DigitalOcean team, then assign the application to each group.
For each role on your DigitalOcean team: 1. From the Okta admin console, expand **Directory** → click **Groups** 2. Click **Add group** and name it with `DO:` prefix followed by the DigitalOcean role name (e.g., `DO:Owner`) 3. Click **Save** to create the group 4. Click the group name → **Applications** tab → **Assign applications** → select your app → **Assign** → **Done**
You must also configure the Groups claim expression in your Okta app's **Sign On** tab to remove the `DO:` prefix and pass the role name as `team_role`.
For detailed instructions, visit [How to Configure Single Sign-On for Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/configure-sso/).

query: {"prompt": "How do I disable SSO on my DigitalOcean team?"}
expected_response:
To disable SSO on a team, switch to the team in the control panel by clicking the profile icon → **Switch Teams** → select your team.
In the left menu, click **Settings** to go to the team settings page. In the **Single sign-on (OIDC)** section, click the **...** menu, then click **Disable**. In the confirmation window, click **Disable SSO**.
Your SSO configuration is saved even when disabled, so you may re-enable it at any time.
For more information, see [How to Configure Single Sign-On for Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/configure-sso/).

query: {"prompt": "Where can I view SSO activity and login history for my team?"}
expected_response:
To view SSO activity, switch to your team in the control panel (profile icon → **Switch Teams** → select team).
In the left menu, click **Settings** to go to the team settings page. In the **Single sign-on (OIDC)** section, click **Show more**, then click **View SSO Activity** to go to the SSO activity page.
This page displays a table with timestamped sign-on history events showing when team members have used SSO to access DigitalOcean.
You can also access this directly at the [SSO activity page](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/account/team/sso/activity) when logged into your team.

query: {"prompt": "What's the difference between SAML and OIDC for SSO, and which should I use?"}
expected_response:
Both SAML and OpenID Connect (OIDC) are secure protocols used for SSO authentication, but they serve different purposes:
**OIDC (OpenID Connect)**: Supported by DigitalOcean Teams, works with OIDC-compatible IdPs like Okta. This is the protocol used for DigitalOcean Teams SSO configuration.
**SAML**: Used by Paperspace Teams, compatible with SAML 2.0 specs and works with identity providers like Google or Auth0.
# Recommendation For DigitalOcean Teams, use OIDC-compatible identity providers. For Paperspace Teams, use SAML-compatible providers. The choice depends on which DigitalOcean service you're configuring.
For DigitalOcean Teams setup, see [How to Configure Single Sign-On for Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/configure-sso/). For Paperspace, see [How to Enable Single Sign-On (SSO) for Paperspace Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/paperspace/accounts-and-teams/enable-sso/).

query: {"prompt": "I'm getting an error when testing my SSO configuration. What should I check?"}
expected_response:
When testing SSO configuration fails, verify these common issues:
**Check your OpenID provider information**: - Ensure the **OpenID provider URL** is correct (e.g., `https://example-application.okta.com`) - Verify the **OpenID client ID** and **client secret** are accurate - Confirm the **Sign-in redirect URI** is set to `https://cloud.digitalocean.com/sessions/sso/callback`
**Verify Okta app configuration**: - Grant type should be set to **Authorization Code** - Remove default `localhost` URI from Sign-out redirect URIs - Check that Groups claim expression is properly configured if using role mapping
# Recommendation Test each component individually: first verify your IdP configuration, then test the connection from DigitalOcean. If issues persist, double-check that your provider URL is a valid OIDC provider before proceeding.
For troubleshooting guidance, see [How to Configure Single Sign-On for Teams](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/teams/how-to/configure-sso/).

query: {"prompt": "I'm setting up my first Droplet on DigitalOcean and need help with SSH key authentication. What's the step-by-step process to set this up?"}
expected_response:
Here's a step-by-step guide to set up SSH key authentication for your new DigitalOcean Droplet:
1. Generate an SSH Key Pair ```bash ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 ``` Press enter to accept the default file location and press enter twice for no passphrase.
2. Add Public Key to DigitalOcean - Log in to your DigitalOcean account - Go to Compute > Droplets - Click on your new Droplet - Select Security > SSH Keys - Click "Add SSH Key" - Paste your public key content (found in ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub) - Name it and click Create
3. Access Your Droplet via SSH ```bash ssh root@your-droplet-ip-address ```
Additional Tips: - Make sure to replace 'root' with your username if you created a new user during droplet setup - Keep your private key secure - never share it - Test connection by running `ping your-droplet-ip` - If using Windows, use PuTTY or WSL for SSH access
Need any clarification on these steps?

query: {"prompt": "How do I set up SSH key authentication for my DigitalOcean server using SnapShooter's backup system?"}
expected_response:
To set up SSH key authentication for your DigitalOcean server using SnapShooter's backup system, follow these steps:
1. From the SnapShooter app, go to the Servers section in the left menu and click "Connect Server +"
2. Choose one of two methods:
   - Use our setup script method:
     * Select your preferred SSH key or generate a new one
     * Copy and paste the provided curl command into your server as root via SSH
     * The script will automatically install the SnapShooter public key

   - Manual setup method:
     * Generate an SSH key pair using `ssh-keygen`
     * Add the public key to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on your DigitalOcean server
     * Enter server details (name, IP/host, username, port)
     * Test connection and add the server

3. Ensure your server meets these requirements:
   - Allow SnapShooter's IP addresses through any firewalls
   - Enable SSH remote root login if needed by editing /etc/ssh/sshd_config
   - Configure NAT gateway settings if applicable

4. After setup, you can proceed with configuring backup jobs for your DigitalOcean server.
Note: Make sure to keep your SSH key secure and never share it with unauthorized users.

query: {"prompt": "How do I set up SSH key-based authentication for my new Droplet? What are the exact steps to generate and add the keys?"}
expected_response:
Here's how to set up SSH key-based authentication for your DigitalOcean Droplet:
1. Generate a new SSH key pair on your local machine: ```bash ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your_email@example.com" ```
2. Add the public key to your DigitalOcean account:
   - Go to your DigitalOcean dashboard
   - Click on Access & Security > SSH Keys
   - Click "Add SSH Key" button
   - Paste your public key content (found in ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub)
   - Give it a name and click "Create"

3. Add the private key to your SSH agent: ```bash eval "$(ssh-agent -s)" ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa ```
4. Test the connection: ```bash ssh root@your_droplet_ip ```
Important notes: - Make sure you have a non-root user set up on your Droplet for better security - You can add multiple keys if needed by repeating steps 2 and 3 - Always keep your private key secure and never share it

query: {"prompt": "What MFA methods are supported?"}
expected_response: DigitalOcean supports the following Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) methods: 1. Authenticator App: DigitalOcean supports authenticator apps such as Google Authenticator, Microsoft Authenticator, and Authy. 2. SMS: DigitalOcean supports SMS-based MFA, where a verification code is sent to your phone via SMS. 3. Backup Codes: DigitalOcean supports single-use codes that act as a second-password in case you lose your 2FA device.

query: {"prompt": "How do I enable two-factor authentication on my DigitalOcean account?"}
expected_response:
To enable 2FA on your DigitalOcean account, access your account settings by clicking the profile icon in the top right of the control panel and selecting 'My Account'. In the 'Two-factor authentication' section select Authentication App or SMS as your default method.
For authentication apps, scan the provided QR code using your authenticator app to link your device to your DigitalOcean account. For SMS, ensure your mobile carrier can deliver text messages. You'll also need to choose a backup method.
We strongly recommend enabling 2FA on all DigitalOcean accounts as it adds an additional layer of security against unauthorized access. Learn more about [managing 2FA](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/accounts/2fa/).

query: {"prompt": "What happens if I log in from a new device without 2FA enabled?"}
expected_response:
Even without 2FA enabled, DigitalOcean takes steps to protect your account. Each time you log in from a new location using a new device or a different web browser, we email an authorization code to the address linked to your account.
You need to check your email, retrieve the code, and enter it to complete your login. This means a bad actor would need both your DigitalOcean password and your email password to log in, which increases the difficulty for would-be attackers and provides you with notification if someone is trying to access your account.
However, we strongly recommend [enabling 2FA](https://docs.digitalocean.com/platform/accounts/2fa/) for stronger security.

query: {"prompt": "How do I change my email address on my DigitalOcean account?"}
expected_response:
To change your email address, access your account settings by clicking the profile icon in the top right of the control panel. Navigate to the "Email and password" section.
After entering your new email address, we send a confirmation email to your new email address to finalize the change. The change does not take effect until you click the link in the confirmation email.
You can manage other account settings through your [Account Settings](https://docs.digitalocean.com/account/profile) page.

query: {"prompt": "Can I switch between different SSO providers for my account?"}
expected_response:
Yes, you can switch between different login options including Google SSO and GitHub SSO. To switch to another account with the same provider, you need to switch to a different login option first and then switch back to select a different account.
You can manage your sign-in methods through your [account settings](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/account/profile). DigitalOcean supports Google SSO, GitHub SSO, as well as traditional email and password authentication.

query: {"prompt": "How do I deactivate my DigitalOcean account?"}
expected_response:
To deactivate your account, you must first complete several prerequisites: delete or transfer ownership of any teams you own and resolve any outstanding bills.
Account deactivation stops billing and prohibits future resource creation. You can optionally purge your account data to permanently remove the account from DigitalOcean and prevent account reactivation.
Access the deactivation option through your [account settings](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/account/profile).

query: {"prompt": "How do I log in if I lose my two-factor authentication device?"}
expected_response:
If you've successfully entered your username and password but don't have access to your 2FA device, you can log in using the backup method you chose when you set up 2FA, which is either backup codes or SMS.
# Recommendation * **Backup codes**: Locate the backup recovery codes text file, which by default is called `digitalocean_backupcodes.txt`. Use one of the codes by logging in to the [control panel](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/login) and clicking **Enter a recovery code** at the bottom of the **Two-factor authentication** screen. When you use the code, you cannot use it again, so you may want to mark it as used or delete it from the file.
* **SMS** Log in to the [control panel](https://cloud.digitalocean.com/login) and enter your account credentials. Click **Send an SMS instead** at the bottom of the **Two-factor authentication** screen. This sends an SMS with a verification code to the phone number you entered when you configured SMS as your backup method. Enter the verification code at the prompt, then click **Verify Code**.
After you log in, update your 2FA device or [disable 2FA](https://docs.digitalocean.com/products/accounts/security/2fa/#disabling-two-factor-authentication).
If you can't use your backup method to access your account, [open a support ticket](https://www.digitalocean.com/company/contact/support) using the email associated with your DigitalOcean account and explain that you need to reset your backup method. In this case, we require additional information to verify that you are the account owner, so be prepared with a photo of your government-issued ID (for example, a passport, driver's license, or military ID). The name on the ID in the photo must match the name for the account information that we have on file.

query: {"prompt": "How do I open a support ticket when I can't log in?"}
expected_response: If you can't sign in to open a ticket, send a support request through the ["Can't sign in?" form](https://www.digitalocean.com/company/contact/support).

query: {"prompt": "What do I do if my account was locked during sign-up?"}
expected_response: If your account is locked during sign-up, [contact DigitalOcean support](https://cloudsupport.digitalocean.com) so we can authorize your access to your account.

query: {"prompt": "Why do I have to keep entering a verification code when I log in?"}
expected_response:
DigitalOcean accounts with email and password sign-ins and no 2FA are protected with device verification by default. Each time you sign in from a new location using a new device or a different web browser, we email an authorization code to the email address you use to sign in or send an SMS to the phone number you provided.
You may be asked to verify your browser from a trusted location and device if you have deleted cookies for digitalocean.com or you have disabled cookies entirely. To allow your browser to be recognized, you can allowlist the verification domain, `siftscience.com`. or pause ad blocking on `*.digitalocean.com`.

query: {"prompt": "I lost access to the GitHub account I use to sign into DigitalOcean"}
expected_response:
If you have lost access to your GitHub account, first try to restore access by following GitHub's account recovery process or 2FA credential recovery process:
* https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/github/authenticating-to-github/updating-your-github-access-credentials * https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/github/authenticating-to-github/recovering-your-account-if-you-lose-your-2fa-credentials
If you can't regain access to your GitHub account, [open a support ticket](https://www.digitalocean.com/company/contact/support) using the email associated with your DigitalOcean account and let us know you need to reset your authentication method. We may need additional information to verify that you are the account owner, so be prepared with a photo of your government-issued ID (for example, a passport, driver's license, or military ID). The name on ID in the photo must match the name for the account information that we have on file.

query: {"prompt": "How do I enforce 2FA for all members of my team?"}
expected_response: Require all team members to use a secure sign-in method through the team **Secure sign-in** setting. This requires team members to use Google, GitHub, or a DigitalOcean account with 2FA enabled. You can configure this setting in your team management area to ensure all members use secure authentication.

query: {"prompt": "How do I lock down my account if I suspect a compromise?"}
expected_response:
Use a backup code to regain access if your 2FA device is compromised, or contact DigitalOcean support immediately. Change your password, rotate all API keys, and review recent account activity for unauthorized changes.
# Recommendation Keep a copy of your backup-code file `digitalocean_backupcodes.txt` securely stored in an encrypted password manager. After securing your account, audit each team member's sign-in method to ensure compliance.

query: {"prompt": "How do I enable Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) on my account?"}
expected_response:
Enable 2FA from the **Two-factor authentication** section of your **My Account** page in the DigitalOcean control panel. Follow the setup process to configure your authenticator app and save your backup codes securely.
# Recommendation Keep a copy of your backup-code file `digitalocean_backupcodes.txt` securely stored in an encrypted password manager.
